DELIVORUS, FELICIUS.

DELIVORUS.</br>Felicius nourish not these sullen vaines,</br>Live not, as if thou lothedst to impart</br>Unto the world thy wisdome and thine art:</br>Vertues obscur'd, yeelds small, and sory gaines</br>But actively imployd, true worth retaines:

Now clattering armes found terror in our coast,</br>Like aged Nestor guirt thee in thy steele,</br>Win fame by valour, let impugners feele,</br>That though sweete Mercurie delights thee most,</br>Thy courage, with thy yeares, thou hast not lost:

FELICIUS.</br>Eld is ordain'd to counsell, youth to fight;</br>Age to fore-see, young courage to enact,</br>High courage with true wisdome ever backt,</br>Winnes perfect fame:  youth doth deserve by might,</br>But old age, by good counsell, and foresight.

Delivorus, when as thou dost beholde</br>Felicius fitte apart, be thou assur'd</br>His mind still works:  and what thou hast endur'd</br>In bloudie brunts, the fame though being olde</br>He doth endure, and more a hundreth folde.

I travaile in my soule, when thou doest sleepe</br>I for my countrie combate by fore-cast,</br>And how by day, the danger shall be past</br>By night I studie:  Thus by care I keepe,</br>What hed-strong youth might loose, and loosing weepe.

I live not then obscurely, as I seeme,</br>But as the master of the ship performes</br>Far more then comon yonkers in great stormes,</br>So guiding of our states well may I deeme,</br>I doe, and merite more, then most esteeme.
DELIVORUS.</br>As if a life devoted unto ease,</br>And mannaging affaires by policie,</br>Might be compar'd for worth, and dignitie</br>With honorable armes, by land and seas?
FELICIUS.</br>Why not (sweet friend) yeeld reason if you please?

DELIVORUS.</br>Whom ever did the rising sunne behold</br>More royalliz'd, and dignified then him,</br>Whose glorie, (though fell fortune sought to dim)</br>His courage rais'd, his conquests manifold,</br>Commaunding all, himselfe still uncontrol'd?

By armes, Realmes, Empires, monarchies are wonne,</br>To armes, lawes, justice, magistrates submit,</br>Arts, sciences, before their triumphes fit,</br>And beg their grace, and ring what they have done,</br>Amas'd to see the race, which they have runne.

FELICIUS.</br>Delivoras, warre, honour doth deserve,</br>Yet counsell in all kingdomes policied</br>Is farre more worthie, and more dignified:</br>For armes, but in extreames doe never serve</br>To reconcile, and punish such as swerve.

First have an eie to Grecian governements,</br>And even in them, the truth will be explain'd.</br>In Athens, where Themistocles remain'd,</br>Though much he conquer'd for his regiments,</br>Yet Solon, was more prais'd for his intents:

Themistocles, by armes; he by good lawes:</br>One, conquered foes, the other planted frends;</br>One got the wealth, the which the other spends,</br>Both fame:  though not like measure, nor like cause:</br>For counsell to it selfe more honour drawes.

Pausanias, and Lysander by their swords,</br>And warlike vertues, made Laocena ritch,</br>Fame followed them where they their tents did pitch,</br>But grave Licurgus, by his lawes and words,</br>Did merite more, then these renowmed Lords,

Though these attempted, he prefixt the way,</br>Though they commanded, and arraung'd the bands,</br>Licurgus put the fortune in their hands:</br>Though Marius could begin, and make the fray,</br>Yet Scaurus policie deserves the bay:

Let Catulus, with Pompey be compar'd,</br>Or wittie Cicero, with Cateline.</br>And to prevent with policie divine</br>That which the other over rathlie dar'd,</br>Deserves such fame as may not be impar'd.

Say militarie vertue doth require</br>A valiant hart, great strength, and constancie:</br>The selfe-like guiftes in civill policie</br>Are requisite for such as doe aspire,</br>To gaine renowne by counsell for their hire:

In briefe, for what is warre ordain'd but peace?</br>And perfect peace is end of bloudie warre:</br>And sith the ends, fore-meanes, is prised farre;</br>Let warre, his boast of dignitie surcease</br>And yeeld to wisdome, which doth peace encrease.

Peace, doth depend on Reason, warre on force,</br>The one is humane, honest, and upright,</br>The other brutish, fostered by despight:</br>The one extreame, concluded with remorse,</br>The other all injustice doth devorce.

DELIVORUS.</br>Felicius thy reasons are approv'd</br>(If measured by the square of statemens skil,</br>Who on their bookes hang their opinions still)</br>But I, who from my youth the warres have lov'd,</br>From mine opinion may not be remov'd.

For by that methode which my selfe have tried</br>I find such word-bold warriors as you be</br>As fit for warre, as apes for minstralsie:</br>For what can you prescribe, or els provide,</br>To order those, whom you could never guide?

Thinke you Vigetius serves to make you fit</br>To give directions to a generall?</br>No book-men no, time now hath changed all,</br>Both men, and meanes:  war craves a greater wit</br>And courage, then when Rome directed it:

Should we expect, (as erst the Romaines did)</br>Instructions to dislodge, encampe, assaile,</br>Before we did endevour to prevaile,</br>The meanes to conquer would be lost, and hid:</br>Basely fights he who warres as others bid.

All things are chang'd, the meanes, the men and armes,</br>Our stratagems now differ from the old,</br>Expert in booke, was never trulie bold,</br>Demosthenes, whose tongue the souldier charmes,</br>Fled coward-like away in hot alarmes.

This said, he ceast, and would no more proceed,</br>Felicius left him setled in his thought,</br>I, hearing both the reasons they had brought,</br>Resolv'd that both deserve true fame indeed,</br>And pray that wit may thrive, and war may speed.</br>
